abstracts.cdata!:
This project was rated highly
            unsatisfactory. However, the social assessment demonstrated
            that the project should be seen in a better light, if only
            because the colleges are likely to improve over time, as
            they reach their "cruising speed" and the
            communities they serve adapt to the new context. Key lessons
            included: Support from senior government officials
            throughout the project is critical; the absence of a clear
            strategic orientation and the very uneven support given the
            project by senior government officials clearly had the
            effect of diverting the attention of staff involved in the
            project toward other priorities. The choice of a site--an
            issue neglected during project preparation--is essential to
            the success of a college in a rural setting: the siting of a
            college must follow, not precede, investment in other
            infrastructure. Community contributions must not be ignored,
            even in countries where traditions of local participation
            are not strong. Local authorities must be given the
            resources to enter into agreements with parent associations
            or nongovernmental organizations in ways that involve the
            latter in managing the college. Putting additional resources
            into the building program cannot compensate for the lack of
            activities designed to improve the quality of instruction.
            In this project, the failure to develop a teacher training
            program specific to rural areas, and the poor performance of
            the two technical assistance activities undoubtedly weakened
            the project's impact.
